description: From Old French posterne, alteration of posterle, from Late Latin posterula (“back door”), from Latin posterus (“later”).

adjectives.description: postern (comparative more postern, superlative most postern)

entries.meaning: A back gate, back door, side entrance, or other gateway distinct from the main entrance.
(archaic) By extension, a separate or hidden way in or out of a place, situation etc.
(historical, military) A subterranean passage communicating between the parade and the main ditch, or between the ditches and the interior of the outworks.
examples: The postern of the enceinte leads through the middle of the curtain, descending from the plane of sight to the ditch
